What do you get from "cat /proc/sys/net/ip_forward"? 

If it's set to 0, IP forwarding is not enabled. If you get 1, that's not the problem, what Linux distribution are you using?

Any time you're running Linux as a VPN server (which functionally makes it a router), IP forwarding must be enabled.

1584106140_1Jgu3kQaBojGnFj82E6Gd3tsyAsKC.body:
It depends. Often the throughput limitations for cable/DOCSIS/HFC are enforced on the modem itself. The configuration payloads(including bandwidth policy) are cryptographically signed by the provider. Unless you can intercept the payloads on the HFC side of the modem, manipulate them, and re-sign them with a trusted key, it's not likely.

Another method is using policy enforcement as your traffic transits the provider network. In a cellular network this is handled by two entities called the PCRF (Policy/Charging Rules Function) and the PCEF (Policy/Charging Enforcement Function). You're going to have a hard time getting past those as ALL of your traffic passes through them - it's encapsulated in a device-specific tunnel (called GTP) until it breaks out just before transiting the PCEF. Cable operators use something similar, including a system by Sandvine (widely used by Comcast to deal with torrent traffic a few years back). 

DSL operators will typically do policy enforcement in a similar tunnel fashion (usually a simple rate/usage limit) if you use PPPoE. If your DSL provider uses DHCP, they'll have something more like Sandvine, much of the time.

In the first scenario, you're basically out of luck, unless they've whitelisted certain services.

In the second scenario, it depends on how good the policy enforcement software is - all systems have blind spots, but they're constantly getting updated, in most cases, to address these. Most of the time, they would go unnoticed, but often, once they're discovered, people go overboard and generate traffic patterns that stand out in metrics.

ISPs are smart these days,  and they have tools to identify abnormal traffic patterns. Unfortunately users take advantage of blind spots and make them blatantly obvious to the network operators - then it gets fixed and no more free HBO weekend.

1533110363_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
Personally, I tend to break routing instead of using a firewall. When I start the VPN, I add static routes specifically for the VPN servers, then remove the default route from the system. 

Once the VPN tunnel comes up, a default route is added via the newly-created tunnel (or two routes via the tunnel: 0.0.0.0/1 and 128.0.0.0/1). As these two routes catch ALL network traffic and are more specific than the default, they will override the default route, even if it had been left in place.

This ensures that the ONLY way traffic can leave the system (toward any network it's not directly connected to) is via the VPN.

NOTE: Do be conscious of your DNS servers. If your VPN server(s) are on your LAN, they will still be reachable and may leak DNS requests unencrypted. Ideally the DNS servers used would be within the VPN provider's network.

1518168486_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
As I understand PRISM, it's a capture of raw data from ISP pipes. Much of it would be encrypted (who knows which private keys they have access to, or if they've implemented MITM in different networks).

The name itself is emblematic of the collection method, as in fiber optic systems. A prism would be used to implement a passive optical tap, sending a duplicate of EVERYTHING that passes across the cable without the sending/receiving party having any indication of a tap.

Often the only indication that a tap is in place is a drop in optical power, but even this could be addressed with amplification.

Bottom line: The operators participating are likely handing over a duplicate of every packet traversing the networks. If you don't control the cryptography end-to-end, or trust the other end's diligence, consider communications public.
